guide.introduction: The TurtleBot mobile robot is designed for both academic and hobbyist researchers. The open-source hardware design provides excellent documentation for adding modifications and extending the capabilities of the robot in hardware or software. The robot is available for purchase as a kit or, if your research budget is limited, this guide will help you build some of the aluminum parts necessary to build your own.
guide.introduction_rendered:
The TurtleBot mobile robot is designed for both academic and hobbyist researchers. The open-source hardware design provides excellent documentation for adding modifications and extending the capabilities of the robot in hardware or software. The robot is available for purchase as a kit or, if your research budget is limited, this guide will help you build some of the aluminum parts necessary to build your own.

Relevant parts
  • 7/16" aluminum round rod
  • Fully Threaded Stud, 6-32 Thread, 1" Length
  • High Strength Threadlocker
Tools
  • #36 drill bit (6-32)
  • 6-32 Tap
  • Hack saw

lines.text: The goal of this guide is to show you how to convert round aluminum stock into a 2" standoff. There are many ways to achieve this, but this is probably the simplest and requires the least expensive tools. This method, however, is not the most accurate.
lines.text_raw: The goal of this guide is to show you how to convert round aluminum stock into a 2" standoff. There are many ways to achieve this, but this is probably the simplest and requires the least expensive tools. This method, however, is not the most accurate.

lines.text: Start with 7/16" rod aluminum stock (1/2" also works) and measure a 2" length.
lines.text_raw: Start with 7/16" rod aluminum stock (1/2" also works) and measure a 2" length.

lines.text: Next, cut the part to length using a hacksaw.
lines.text_raw: Next, cut the part to length using a hacksaw.

lines.text: A file can be used to clean up the rough end and a bit of emery paper can be used to remove the burrs on the edge.
lines.text_raw: A file can be used to clean up the rough end and a bit of emery paper can be used to remove the burrs on the edge.

lines.text: The center head of a combination square set can be used to mark the center of the rod.
lines.text_raw: The center head of a combination square set can be used to mark the center of the rod.

lines.text: A center punch can be used to help start the drill bit.
lines.text_raw: A center punch can be used to help start the drill bit.

lines.text: A center drill is a short drill bit that can be used to start the hole. Drill in about 3-5mm or about halfway down the the conical portion.
lines.text_raw: A center drill is a short drill bit that can be used to start the hole. Drill in about 3-5mm or about halfway down the the conical portion.

lines.text: Use a #36 (0.1065") drill bit to make a hole about 0.7" deep.
lines.text_raw: Use a #36 (0.1065") drill bit to make a hole about 0.7" deep.

lines.text: Once the hole is finished, turn it upside down and knock it against the table to remove chips.
lines.text_raw: Once the hole is finished, turn it upside down and knock it against the table to remove chips.

lines.text: Using a #6-32 tap and cutting fluid, tap the hole 0.5" deep. Keep the tap straight and turn the tap one full turn forwards and a quarter turn backwards and repeat until finished. Do not force the tap and don't break the tap or you will spoil the work and have to start over.
lines.text_raw: Using a #6-32 tap and cutting fluid, tap the hole 0.5" deep. Keep the tap straight and turn the tap one full turn forwards and a quarter turn backwards and repeat until finished. Do not force the tap and don't break the tap or you will spoil the work and have to start over.

lines.text: Repeat the same procedure for the other end.
lines.text_raw: Repeat the same procedure for the other end.

lines.text: Once both ends are tapped a 1" threaded stud will be used to create the male threads.
lines.text_raw: Once both ends are tapped a 1" threaded stud will be used to create the male threads.

lines.text: Apply a "red" permanent-strength thread locker to a 0.5" length of the stud and screw it into one end of the spacer.
lines.text_raw: Apply a "red" permanent-strength thread locker to a 0.5" length of the stud and screw it into one end of the spacer.

lines.text: Wipe off the excess thread locker with a paper towel and you have now finished one spacer.
lines.text_raw: Wipe off the excess thread locker with a paper towel and you have now finished one spacer.

lines.text: The TurtleBot will require eight 2" standoffs, so you may want to make them all at once.
lines.text_raw: The TurtleBot will require eight 2" standoffs, so you may want to make them all at once.
